questions: Little interest or pleasure in doing things.
Trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much.
Feeling tired or having little energy.
Feeling bad about yourself — or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down.
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television.
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed. Or the opposite — being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual.
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way.

Minimal or None.characteristics: No or very few symptoms of depression. General mood and energy are stable.
Minimal or None.strengths: Good resilience and ability to manage stress. Daily functioning is not impaired.
Minimal or None.blindspots: Early warning signs can be overlooked; small mood dips may be dismissed.
Minimal or None.advice: Maintain healthy routines: regular sleep, exercise, balanced nutrition, and meaningful social connection. Continue monitoring well-being, especially during times of stress or transition.

Mild.characteristics: Some symptoms of low mood, fatigue, or negative thinking are present, but they may not severely affect functioning.
Mild.strengths: Awareness and early recognition of symptoms allow for preventive action.
Mild.blindspots: Symptoms can worsen if ignored. Stress or life events may increase vulnerability.
Mild.advice: Build coping strategies now: exercise, journaling, prayer/meditation, or therapy. Talk with a trusted friend, mentor, or counselor. Monitor symptoms over 2–3 weeks; if persistent, consider professional evaluation.

Moderate.characteristics: Symptoms are noticeable and affect motivation, sleep, appetite, or concentration. Daily functioning may be impacted.
Moderate.strengths: You are aware of the challenges and may already be considering support.
Moderate.blindspots: Symptoms may interfere with work, relationships, or health if untreated.
Moderate.advice: Seek professional support (e.g., counselor, psychologist, or physician). Consider therapy or counseling to develop strategies. Establish routines: physical activity, sleep hygiene, supportive relationships. Avoid isolation.

Moderately Severe.characteristics: Symptoms are strong and frequent, likely interfering with most areas of life. Emotional pain may feel heavy and difficult to manage alone.
Moderately Severe.strengths: Recognizing the severity is a strong step toward healing.
Moderately Severe.blindspots: Without support, symptoms may worsen or lead to significant impairment.
Moderately Severe.advice: Seek professional help promptly. Discuss therapy and possible medical treatment with a healthcare provider. Strengthen social support, limit isolation, and engage in small, manageable activities to build momentum.

Severe.characteristics: Severe symptoms significantly impair functioning. May include hopelessness, loss of energy, or recurring thoughts of self-harm.
Severe.strengths: Awareness creates an opportunity to urgently get help.
Severe.blindspots: Waiting or self-isolating increases risk of harm.
Severe.advice: Seek immediate professional support (doctor, counselor, mental health provider). If you have thoughts of self-harm or suicide, please call your local emergency number or a crisis hotline right away. Share openly with a trusted person. Early treatment can greatly improve outcomes.
